title: Federal Charges Against Don Lemon for Church Protest Coverage
summary: Don Lemon, a former CNN anchor, was arrested in Los Angeles and faces federal civil rights charges related to his coverage of an anti-immigration enforcement protest at Cities Church in St. Paul, Minnesota. The protest occurred on January 18, 2026, disrupting a church service where a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement official serves as pastor. Lemon, along with independent journalist Georgia Fort and two protest participants, was indicted by a grand jury in Minnesota on charges of conspiracy and interfering with First Amendment rights of worshippers. After a court appearance, Lemon was released and struck a defiant tone, vowing to continue his journalism and fight the charges, pleading not guilty. He asserts that he was at the protest as a solo journalist documenting events, with no affiliation to the protest organization. This case highlights tensions between press freedom and legal boundaries during civil demonstrations, with Lemon's defense attorney, Marilyn Bednarski, supporting his stance. The charges stem from allegations that their actions violated civil rights during the protest, raising broader questions about media accountability and protection under the law.

background_read: This article discusses a high-profile legal case involving Don Lemon, a journalist known for his work at CNN until his dismissal in 2023. In early 2026, he was arrested for covering an anti-immigration protest at a Minnesota church, leading to federal civil rights charges. The protest targeted a church where a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement official is a pastor, highlighting ongoing debates over immigration enforcement in the U.S. Lemon's arrest underscores the complex relationship between journalism and the law, particularly regarding the First Amendment, which protects freedom of the press. The case involves a grand jury indictment, a legal process where citizens review evidence to determine if charges are warranted. Understanding this context helps middle school students grasp how media professionals navigate legal challenges while reporting on contentious issues, and it encourages critical thinking about rights and responsibilities in a democracy.
